Fields.DialogueText: I see you've found yourself in my chair again.
It's technically a part of me, Kapitän, so I can hardly be out of bounds.
Uh-huh. What is that, a picture?

Fields.MenuText: Whoa, that is one scary, scary man.
Huh, I didn't know Belles had sweethearts.
That is one magnificent mustache.

Fields.DialogueText: Ne? Oh, no, he's... never mind.
Ne? İmkanı yok! It's not like that.
Ne? Oh, yeah... sure.
So who is he?
He's no one.
How interesting! Our kind Lady Yavuz is carrying around a picture of a man she doesn't want anyone to know about. Hahaha, the intrigue!
Fine, I'll get out of your chair.
I didn't mean any offense.
... Captain, Al Ana approaching from the east.
Of course there is.
@BATTLE
Yavuz, are you playing chess against yourself?
Yes, Kapitän.
Why?
An old friend of mine used to do this. It's good practice in tactical maneuvering. It teaches you to see situations from all angles.

Fields.MenuText: How long have you been playing this particular game?
Which "you" wins?
Doesn't that get confusing?

Fields.DialogueText: About two hours.
Whichever "me" is performing better that day.
I suppose some people would get confused.
That is...
Kapitän, it seems we're coming upon a monster ship.
@BATTLE
So, Yavuz, want to play a game?
Sorry, Kapitän, I have things I need to do. Üzgünüm.
What's wrong with her?
Yavuz, I think we should talk for a moment.
Yes, Kapitän? Benden ne istiyorsun?
You've seemed out of sorts lately. Is something wrong? Did I do something?
No, Kapitän, it's nothing.
Let's see, how can I communicate this more clearly? Yavuz, you're not leaving this room until you've told me what's going on.
Fine. It's just... Well... I'm...
That man in the picture I had... that was my old admiral, Wilhelm Souchon. I've been worried about him.
Worried? Why?
The last thing I heard about him was that he was displaced in a mutiny. I haven't been able to find out anything else since.

Fields.MenuText: Well, I'm sure he's all right.
Do you think he's in trouble?
Is there something I can do to help?

Fields.DialogueText: Evet... you're probably right...
I'm worried that he could be.
You wouldn't happen to know any private investigators, would you?
*ALARM*
Hold that thought... looks like we have a Morgana on our hands.
@BATTLE
Oh, Yavuz, good! I wanted to speak with you.
Not now, sir.
Al Ana on our tail.
@BATTLE
Now then, what did you want to talk to me about?
I want you to meet someone.
Yavuz, this is Marco DiMarco. Mr. DiMarco's an inquiry agent. I've asked him to look into Admiral Souchon's whereabouts.
It's a pleasure, Bella Yavuz. Let me assure you, if anyone can track down your admiral, it's me.
I would be happy to get started... as soon as someone can point me to the head. I think seasickness is getting the best of me.
It's over there.
Kapitän, I... I don't know how to thank you.

Fields.MenuText: There's no need, Yavuz.
You might wait to thank me until we actually find Souchon.
I'm just glad I can help.

Fields.DialogueText: Still, it means a lot to me. Thank you. Çok tesekkür ederim!
Haha, true. We'll see.
That's very kind of you, Kapitän. Çok teşekkür ederim.
So, where do we start?
Well, we start with Yavuz telling us everything she knows about Souchon's personal life. Is Souchon married? Does he have a family?
I... I don't know. It seems odd, but Souchon never talked about his life back home.
What about biographical information? Where is he from? What about his extended family?
I don't know much. He was born in Leipzig. He used to talk about being a Huguenot... Like I said, he never spoke much about his family.
Now that I think about it, he did have a nephew. Souchon was proud of him because he fought in the war and joined the Imperial Navy.
Do you know any other information about his nephew?
Just his name. Hermann Souchon.
Good, good. I'll see about tracking down Signore Hermann. Meanwhile, you two keep working on remembering anything useful about the admiral.
Kapitän, it looks as if a Morgana has appeared on the western horizon.
I'll tell the crew to sound the alarm.
And there's my cue. I'll be in the head. There's no need to look in on me. I'll come out when the ship stops rocking.
@BATTLE
All right, DiMarco says we need to think of anything that could help him locate Admiral Souchon. What other possibilities are there?
What did he like to do? I mean, when he had free time, how did he occupy himself? Any hobbies or interests?
Well, mostly, he just loved reading and having company.
So, he was a social sort?
In a laidback kind of way. He enjoyed conversation, but he didn't need attention.
And what did he read?
He enjoyed history, especially reading about naval officers. That, and philosophy. He was interested in religious politics, since they played such a big role in the war.
Really, he was interested in anything that would make him a better officer.

Fields.MenuText: He sounds like me.
He sounds like a great man.
And that made you admire him.

Fields.DialogueText: Haha. You really think so?
Evet. He was an excellent man.
It did. So much of what I try to be is based on who he is.
Sir, there's a Morgana swiftly closing in.
To be continued, Yavuz.
@BATTLE
Kapitän!
We have another Al Ana on our hands!
Everyone to battle stations!
@BATTLE
Have we seen DiMarco? That battle could not have helped with his seasickness...
I'm all right, Captain. I've gotten accustomed to holding on for dear life in my bunk.
Now then, back to the search for the admirable admiral. Let me tell you, Yavuz, your friend has some interesting relations.
What do you mean?
I wasn't actually able to speak with his nephew - he's back in the service and off on a campaign - but it turns out Hermann Souchon is a little bit famous.
For what?
For assassinating radical communist activists.

Fields.MenuText: I did not see that coming.
Looks like the apple rolled pretty far from the tree after it landed.
HE'S AN ASSASSIN!? HAHAHAHAHA...

Fields.DialogueText: That's probably what made him a good assassin.
No kidding.
I just... I have no words.
It gets better. He fled the country after the incident and became a banker in Finland. It seems he laid low there until he was commissioned again by the Luftwaffe and returned to Germany.
I'm guessing that means he wouldn't have much intel on his uncle even if we could talk to him.
Correct. We'll have to find another lead.
Well, his family provided no useful information, so now let's start with the last you heard of him, Yavuz.
I'm not sure how much help that will be. It's been about twenty years since I've heard anything.
We have no way of knowing what information would be helpful at this point, so we might as well hear everything.
Souchon was stationed at Kiel, right?
Yes, he was the commanding officer of the naval base there.
Wait, was he...
Evet. He was the commanding officer at the time of the mutiny. He had only been there three days when it started.
He had no way of knowing what had been going on with the sailors, and he had no rapport with them to try and work things out.
He wanted to bring in outside troops for support, but his staff told him everything was in hand.
When the troops were finally brought in, they were unorganized, and some even joined the rebellion.
Yavuz... that mutiny helped spark the German Revolution, didn't it?
Yes. It must have broken his heart. He resigned immediately afterward. They replaced him with a politician. It's maddening.

Fields.MenuText: It's sad.
We'll find him, Yavuz.
Maybe it was a good thing.

Fields.DialogueText: How does someone recover from that?
Will we?
What makes you say that?
From what you said, Souchon is a capable, resilient man. Surely, whatever he went on to do, he did it well and found some sort of happiness for himself.
He's sure to be known and loved by whoever's around him. That will help us find him.
Kapitän...
No, no - I know it sounds trite, but I think it's true.
No, Kapitän, we've come upon an enemy fleet.
@BATTLE
I think every time we go through another battle, my hair gets a little grayer.
Benimle dalga mı geçiyorsun? What are you talking about? That was invigorating!
How is it that in normal circumstances, you're always so serious and severe, but when you're being fired at and fighting for your life, you're suddenly gregarious and upbeat?
I think that's called adrenaline, sir.

Fields.MenuText: Well, I like it. We should get into harrowing ship battles more often.
Well, it's scary. I don't know what to do with you when you're chipper, Yavuz.
Haha, is that what it is?

Fields.DialogueText: Sounds good to me.
Just set me upon some unsuspecting Morganas.
Either that, or I just enjoy doing what I was designed for.
Oh, DiMarco, you look not as sick as usual. Are you getting used to warfare at sea?
What can I say? It's growing on me. I came to tell you what I've heard from contacts in Kiel.
Yes?
I'm afraid that the admiral's short tenure there and the unfortunate nature of his resignation meant he didn't keep up contact with any of his officers.
We'll have to look for other leads. But first... I need a nap.
Don't get discouraged. We'll find him, Yavuz.
*ALARM*
That's easier said than done, Kapitän.
@BATTLE
So, we need to give DiMarco more to go off of, and we should do so strategically.
Right. We can't afford to miss anything.
I'm thinking we should work backwards through Souchon's career and see if anything sticks out. We've covered Kiel and the mutiny. Where was he before that?
He was a commander in the High Seas Fleet. He was with them during Operation Albion.
The High Seas Fleet? You had a sister ship in that fleet, didn't you?
Yes... Moltke.
You're sad? Oh... she was still in the fleet when...
When Germany surrendered and the fleet was scuttled.

Fields.MenuText: I really need to learn when to stop talking.
I'm so sorry, Yavuz.
That's awful.

Fields.DialogueText: Heh. Evet. It's an invaluable skill to have.
It's all right. It was a long time ago.
That's just what happens to warships... happens to all of us, eventually.
*ALARM*
Well, no time to sit and brood about it. Al Ana on our six. Get ready.
@BATTLE
An enemy approaches, and so we raise our swords yet again.
Prepare yourselves. Cesur olmalıyız.
@BATTLE
Another victory in the books, and I am glad to be alive. Everybody gets a pass on exceeding alcohol rations today!
What has you in such a good mood? We were just - how did you put it earlier? "Being fired at and fighting for our lives?"
True, but your attitude about battle has me thinking.
For today, at least, I have decided that any time we come out alive is cause to celebrate. We shouldn't be worrying over the fact that we could have just died.
Yavuz, pull out whatever your German or Turkish drink of choice is, and join me in celebrating.
This would be an excellent time to challenge you to a drinking competition. After all, my drinks of choice are non-alcoholic.

Fields.MenuText: You're no fun.
What? You're not going to join me in celebrating?
Okay, then, what is your favorite drink?

Fields.DialogueText: Maybe not, but it will be fun for me to be sober and mess with you while you're hungover.
I can join in the celebrating just as easily without the alcohol, I assure you.
Ayran, as usual. Have any salt around?
I'm surprised you don't drink, Yavuz. What's the story there?
There's more than one reason, but I bet you can guess one of the obvious ones.
Ah, the admirable admiral didn't drink. Of course.
He would on occasion, but it had to be the right occasion. He didn't smoke, either. He liked people, and he liked having fun, but it was important for him to maintain self-control.
A wise policy. One others should probably consider adopting. Now, shall we toast?
I think so.
To the admiral.
To the admiral.
Looking at Admiral Souchon's service record is pretty daunting. The man is skillful, self-assured, and seriously intimidating.
It was funny to see his two sides. There was the Souchon who could navigate any social situation and make people feel welcome and comfortable.
And then there was the in-command Souchon, who was not someone you'd want to trifle with. He was stoic and always in complete control of any situation.
Did you know he earned the Pour le Mérite? He was in Germany's highest military order.
The intimidation continues.
And they just let him disappear. How does that even happen?
Maybe we're missing the obvious. Maybe he wanted to disappear. His career ended in an awful way. Maybe he needed a fresh start.
Even if that's the case, Souchon devoted his life to fighting for Germany - even when it was clear they would lose - and they abandoned him. It's not fair.
It's true that things aren't the way they should be. Souchon didn't deserve what happened. Still, if anyone could come back from that kind of blow, I think it would be him.
Tamam. I've had enough with being depressed about the state of the world. We need a distraction. What do you say?

Fields.MenuText: Put on the record of "Lili Marlene" and have a dance?
Go order ensigns to carry out ridiculous challenges?
Go up to the deck and enjoy the fresh air?

Fields.DialogueText: You know I love Lale Anderson.
You know I love seeing their confused faces.
You know, that sounds great.
Sir! We have an incoming Morgana!
Just a quick battle, and then we'll resume distracting ourselves.
@BATTLE
Yavuz! I've been looking for you. Where have you been?
I just... I wanted to be alone.
What's wrong?
Bir yanlıs yok. It's stupid. It's nothing.
Come on. Out with it.
What if... what if that happens to me? What if the Protection Force decides I'm worthless, like Germany did with Souchon?
What if I outgrow my usefulness? What if they decide to scuttle me? I'd rather go down in a fight than meet that sort of end.

Fields.MenuText: Yavuz, how can you talk like that?
I wouldn't let that happen.
You're probably right.

Fields.DialogueText: ...You're right. Pessimism won't help anything.
Thank you, Kapitän. But I'm pretty sure there's little you could actually do to stop it.
Kapitän! You're not supposed to agree with me! You're supposed to help me rally!
You know why that's not going to happen to you? Because everyone knows you're a tough old ship who will never die.
What did the Turks name you?
... Yavuz.
And why? Because they know you are brazenly capable and can turn even the bleakest of situations to your advantage.
You won't outlive your usefulness, and no one's going to scuttle you. Not on my watch.
You're delusional...  but you're also encouraging.
Sir! There's a Morgana approaching!
Come on, Yavuz! Let's show them why it's a mistake to mess with you.
@BATTLE
It seems talking about Souchon's time in Germany hasn't been helpful, so let's focus on Turkey for a while. How was his career over there?
Honestly, not much better than his time at Kiel, which is sad to say. His initial campaign, bombing Russia's Black Sea ports, was a success, but after that things were much harder.
Harder in what way?
Souchon really wanted to help improve Turkey's management of their Navy and shipping operations, but none of the officials would listen to him.
He also asked for more support to keep Russian submarines in the Black Sea at bay, but they never approved it.
I'll take it that means I shouldn't go looking for Souchon in Turkey.
No. I think all the bridges there were conclusively burned.
How did his spirits hold up, being where no one would listen to him?
He was frustrated, sure, but at the same time, Souchon wasn't one to let frustration pull him down. He kept serving to the best of his abilities. Kind of like you.

Fields.MenuText: You think so?
I don't know about that, but thank you.
I'll take it!

Fields.DialogueText: Yeah. You're pretty indomitable.
Souchon couldn't take a compliment, either.
Well good! It's a good quality to have.
*ALARM*
Now don't be alarmed, but it sounds like we have a Morgana approaching.
@BATTLE
Yavuz? Are you awake?
Ne haber? Oh, Kapitän - I must have dozed off.
It's pretty uncharacteristic of you to be sleeping on the job.
Sorry, Kapitän. I was up late last night.
Doing what?
Regaling our sailors with the story of destroying Prut. It's impossible for me to tell it without getting a little over-excited!

Fields.MenuText: That much is obvious.
Well, don't wear yourself out with all this storytelling. We still need you to be fit for battle.
Ooh, will you tell it to me? It definitely sounds exciting!

Fields.DialogueText: What? I can't help it.
Ah, don't worry Kapitän. I'm not slacking on my duties.
Prehaps another time!
Haha, to think of it now! Those ridiculous Russians hardly knew what to do with us. Souchon was in fine form that day.
Even when he realized his actions caused Russia to declare war on Turkey?
Oh, that was Souchon's intention from the beginning.
What?
Heh, I'll tell you later. Al Ana ahead.
@BATTLE
Yavuz, don't you owe me an explanation regarding Souchon and Turkey?
Even - tabi ki. It's simple, really.
Although Souchon technically became an officer in the Ottoman Navy, he was always still in the service of Germany. However, Souchon was wise in how he went about that.
While other German officers in the Ottoman Navy tried outright to convince Turkey to support Germany in the war, Souchon focused his efforts improving their Navy.
Eventually, he became the General Commander of the Turkish fleet and was able to make the decision himself to bombard the Russian Black Sea Ports.
He knew Russia would declare war in retaliation, and Turkey would have to align themselves with Germany.
That's... quite a call to make.
I know. I'm loyal to Turkey, and I do try to see what he did through that lens - but his decisiveness and determination were incredible.
True, but I'm not sure it was right decision. Didn't that end up leading to the dissolution of the Ottoman Empire?
That's a lot of trouble for a country that didn't want to be in the war.

Fields.MenuText: I'm not saying he was wrong. I'm just not sure he was right.
It seems reckless to me.
That just seems like a difficult choice.

Fields.DialogueText: I take your point. But, at the same time, Turkey is healthier now than the Ottoman Empire was for centuries. It's possible that...
I don't think anyone could accuse Souchon of being reckless, but maybe you have a point.
It takes a strong person to make a difficult decision and live with it.
*BOOM*
Oh! That would be the sound of heavy artillery. Here we go again...
@BATTLE
Yavuz, did I hear you yelling profanities and insults earlier?
Evet. I'm sorry if that was alarming.
No, it wasn't that. I was just curious what drew that kind of ire out of you.
Oh, it was just Winston Churchill.
Not the answer I was expecting. What did he do?
Nothing recently. Someone mentioned him last night, and I can't help but get angry any time he comes up. He's a horrible man.
What makes you say that?
Well, it's nearly all personal bias. First, he ordered the appropriation of two Turkish ships without compensating the Turkish government.
Leaving an opening for you and the Breslau in their fleet?
Hush. Second, he said that I caused more slaughter, more misery, and more ruin for the people of the Middle East than any other ship.
That seems... severe...
Third, he's just always seemed like a deeply unpleasant person. He's always so impetuous and unfeeling, not to mention, he always thinks he's right.

Fields.MenuText: Sounds like someone I know.
Sounds like me...
That's probably what made him an effective official.

Fields.DialogueText: I do not... Oh, I'm about to prove your point, aren't I?
Perhaps, but at least your sphere of influence is smaller.
Fine. I will admit he is well-suited to his job.
Actually, Churchill and Souchon seem to have similar philosophies on making decisions that will affect other people.
Now I'm imagining Souchon and Churchill having dinner together and trying to have a civil conversation. I don't think it would go well.
Probably not.
Sir! There's a Morgana approaching!
So much for civil conversations.
@BATTLE
Yavuz! Captain! Do I have a story for YOU!
Just one moment, DiMarco! We have a Morgana on our hands! Better hunker down!
@BATTLE
Everything all right, DiMarco?
Let's just say I'll be very happy to be on dry land once more. And once I am, I will never step off it again.
So what's the story?
Bad news first. The lead fell short of actually getting me in contact with Souchon. The good news is, I learned a bit more about what he did after the Kiel mutiny.
I was able to speak with an officer in the Imperial Navy who attempted to ask Souchon to join the service again for a top-secret mission.
Attempted to ask? Meaning he failed?
He said a few years ago he was asked to go to Souchon's house in Bremen and offer him a commission.
He wasn't expecting Souchon's housekeeper to be so fiercely protective of him that she wouldn't even let the officer enter the house. She chased him off with a broom and a guard dog.
He returned to the house to try again a few weeks later, but Souchon was gone. I guess he really was trying to disappear.
So, what you're saying is, not even the Imperial Navy can contact him.
It's possible they did succeed in commissioning him again, and he's back at sea now. That could explain why we're having trouble connecting him to anyone.
Perhaps...
Kapitän...
Yes, Yavuz?
I've been thinking about what you said- that Souchon could be fighting at sea again. What if... what if he is... and the reason we can't find him is because he's already been killed?
Yavuz, where is this coming from?
He's getting older. It's not out of the realm of possibility for him to feel the need to prove himself. That can make a person reckless.
I thought you said no one could ever accuse him of being reckless.
I did, but twenty years is a long time. People change. If he thinks he has something to prove, he's more likely to make a mistake. One bad encounter with a Morgana, and he could be gone.

Fields.MenuText: I think, no matter how old he is, Souchon is smarter than that.
Honestly, I don't think any Morgana could take down Souchon, even on her best day, no matter how old he is.
I don't think Souchon is capable of dying. I think he would just refuse to die, and Death would have to say, "Sorry, my mistake. I'll be going now."

Fields.DialogueText: Evet. You're right. I should have more faith in him.
Now you're just trying to cheer me up.
Haha, that sounds about right.
Sorry to interrupt, sir. There's a Morgana approaching from the south.
What do you say? Let's go teach her a lesson.
@BATTLE
Kasar. Back for more, monster girls? Come at me, then!
@BATTLE
Another victory in the books.
You know, Yavuz, we've been working backward through the admiral's service record for a while now, and I still haven't heard the story of evading the British fleet.
You've been waiting for that one?
I've heard about it before, but getting the story from the ship herself should be pretty good.
Haha, I suppose it would be. Well, Germany had us stationed in the Adriatic so that, if war broke out, we would be able to stop French military transports.
My boilers needed repairs, so we had stopped in Pola. As soon as Souchon heard about the archduke, he knew we needed to get out.
Meanwhile, Churchill had dispatched Admiral Milne to shadow us and keep us from interfering with those French transports.
Souchon had already planned to bomb Bône and Philippeville, but he was given an order to proceed to Constantinople for refuge. Souchon decided to bomb them anyway.
The French thought we would escape west to Gibraltar, but we were already heading east, to Ottoman territory.
The British tried to intercept us, because they still thought we were going to attack the French transports. Breslau held them off while I sought further repairs in the Aegean.
After that, we made our way to the Turkish straits, narrowly evading the British fleet.
When the Turks finally allowed us passage, Souchon looked back and could see the smoke from the British ships appearing on the horizon.
We became Turkish ships that very moment in order to take advantage of Turkey's neutrality. There was nothing the British could do.

Fields.MenuText: That's really impressive.
It sounds like you were really lucky.
It's almost funny how that unfolded.

Fields.DialogueText: I think so.
We really were.
It really is.
It truly was a strange combination of cleverness and luck. There are so many things that, if they were even a second off in timing, if they had been communicated differently...
Well, everything could have turned out very differently.
Captain! I wanted to let you know I got in contact with my friend at Kiel, and he's going to check around, like you asked.
Thanks, DiMarco.
What was that about?
We'll see.
We will litter the sea with your machinery, nixe!
@BATTLE
I tell you, Yavuz, I cannot wait for this whole Morgana problem to be taken care of. All these battles are getting tiresome.
You say that like you would be doing something different if the Morganas weren't around.
Wouldn't I?
It's not as if a Kapitän gets a lot of free time, even if there's not a war going on. The truth is, in this age, war has always been just around the corner. At best.
Souchon saw that. That's why he was adamant about getting my repairs done, even though Germany wasn't actively in a war. He wanted to be ready, in case what he felt would happen did.
And then when the archduke was assassinated, he knew we had to move quickly. It was only a matter of time before we'd be caught in the fray.
Well that's... depressing.
That's the life of a Kapitän.
What if I weren't a captain?
You're thinking about quitting?
No, not really. It's nice to think about it sometimes, though... what would I do if I could do anything?

Fields.MenuText: I could see more of the world than just port towns.
I could have a family of my own.
I could become a circus performer, like I wanted to when I was six.

Fields.DialogueText: What is it, Yavuz?
Kapitän...
I think I would miss you a lot if you left.
Well, I'm not going anywhere any time soon.
"Nixe?"
I do still know German.
Yavuz, you're brooding.
What?
I can practically smell it coming off of you. You're wrapped up in thought about something, and it's not a cheerful something. Out with it.
I was thinking about my sister, Moltke.
The one who was in the High Seas fleet.
Evet. Did you know she was supposed to take my place in the Mediterranean?
Really?
She was supposed to come relieve me in Pola. I still had repairs that needed to be done, and she was better equipped anyway.
What changed?
The assassination. They didn't have time to make the switch. If they had... I never would have been left in Turkey. Moltke might never have been scuttled.
You can't let yourself think like that.
Why not?

Fields.MenuText: Because it will drive you insane.
Because it's not reality.
Because it will give you a headache.

Fields.DialogueText: I can be rather maudlin sometimes, can't I?
Nothing's going to change it, huh?
Ack, and I already have enough reasons for those.
*ALARM*
And furthermore, I need your mind here right now, because we have a Morgana coming up on us!
Tabii efendim.
@BATTLE
You know, Yavuz, I don't know anything about what you did before Souchon was assigned to you.
That's probably because there wasn't much that happened. I was only in the Navy for a little over a year before Souchon took command.
In any case, I was built in Hamburg, and when the First Balkan War broke out, I was moved to the Mediterranean to protect German interests.
But there wasn't much action then. I mostly just hopped port-to-port before settling in Pola.
And then the Second Balkan War started, you couldn't leave the Mediterranean, and Souchon was assigned to you.
Evet. I remember the first day he stepped aboard. He was so tall. I don't even know if he was actually that tall, but in my mind, he was towering.
Before he even spoke, I could sense that he had everything under control. He wasn't only going to keep us safe, but he was going to lead us to do great things.
And looking back, do you feel you did great things?
I don't know. We certainly did impressive things, but it might be too early to tell if we did good things.

Fields.MenuText: Well, there's no point in worrying about it.
Well, we can make sure to do good things now.
Well, at least you've been impressive.

Fields.DialogueText: You're right. I shouldn't brood over it.
You're right. I should make the best of every moment.
Haha! You're horrible!
Captain, a package arrived for you.
What is it?
Just a gift for a friend. It can wait. For now, it seems we're coming up on a Morgana.
@BATTLE
You'll regret this, Al Ana!
@BATTLE
Yavuz, a moment, please.
Yes, DiMarco?
I think it's time to admit we're not going to find Souchon. If I come across anything in the future, I'll be sure to let you know.
As it happens, my services have been retained by a man in Italy who's convinced his wife is having an affair. You know how to contact me if you need anything.
Thank you for your good work, DiMarco. Have fun being back on land.
Oh, I will enjoy it very much.
You don't seem too disappointed.
Oddly, I'm not.
Why is that?
I spent so long idolizing Admiral Souchon, I don't think I ever stopped to think about the impact his actions actually had on the world.
I think, really, he was a good man, but I also think a lot of people suffered because of his decisions...
All of the confusion and fighting from the Ottoman Empire being split up... it was Souchon's decision to attack those Black Sea ports that started that chain of events.
And that means I'm culpable for the bad side of that too.

Fields.MenuText: It's not your fault.
I guess so.
Yavuz...

Fields.DialogueText: Denying it won't make it better.
But I won't let it pull me down.
It's all right.
What we're doing now - fighting the Morganas, protecting the seas so the war can be a fair fight - it's my chance to make up for what I've done.
In some ways, I think I'll always wonder about what happened to Souchon, but at the same time, he's not my Kapitän anymore.
I have a new Kapitän, one I know I can trust to do the right thing.
"Nixe" actually does seem more on  point for a sea monster. Isn't an Al Ana kind of a riverside creature?
I'm imagining these things beached and helpless.
Fair enough, then.
Back for more, Al Ana? Come at me!
@BATTLE
Yavuz, wait a moment. Let's have a drink.
Kapitän, you know I don't drink much.

Fields.MenuText: Just... take the drink.
True, but you drink if you have a good reason.
Fine, but it's better if you take the drink.

Fields.DialogueText: If you insist... what's this about?
Also true. So, what's my reason?
What's better? What are you talking about?
This drink is for two things: commiserating our failure to find Souchon and celebrating our success in finding... this.
A notebook? What is it?
I had DiMarco contact some people at Kiel to see if Souchon left any personal items. It wasn't looking hopeful, until one of Souchon's old officers remembered he had this.
Take a look.
Oh!
It's his journal from 1914. He covers everything - all of his thoughts on everything that happened.
It's all there. The assassination of the archduke, realizing war was coming, knowing he needed to get you repaired, and evading the British fleet.
Then, there's his decision to destroy Russia's Black Sea ports, realizing it would thrust Turkey into the war. He really was an extraordinary man.
He knew difficult times were ahead, but he was glad to have such reliable and fierce ships as the Yavuz and the Breslau with him. He really depended on you.
Thank you, Kapitän. I don't know what to say.

Fields.MenuText: Well, Yavuz, what are friends for?
Yavuz... I think you should know that... that I... I would do anything for you.
